Bennet Zhu

November 22
History, arts, and writing enthusiast
Former bullied kids, what did your bullies do when they met you as an adult?

“When I grow up I’m going to f****** kill you”

That was the promise I gave my childhood bully after one particular beatdown he gave me. In reply he picked up the glasses he knocked off my face, snapped them in half and threw them at me before laughing and walking away.

At home my parents were going through a violent divorce so I got punished SO BAD for ‘breaking my new expensive glasses’. But I took it all in silence. I didn’t want to tell anyone and get their help. I wanted the satisfaction, the pleasure, of getting revenge myself. [Note: this is an absolutely detestable mentality. If you’re going through the same issues I am, find someone who can help. This kind of thinking is just 100% the worst move you can make and I was stupid enough as a kid to make it]

That day I promised myself I would never ever ever let it go.

The rest of the time I spent around him was spent in an absolute agonising rage. Why? Because he was always unquestionably stronger than me, he always top of the class academically and he was more popular. It would be that anger that drove my mentality well into my teens.

Training to take it all back

Well, 200 pull ups a day, 2 km runs a day and one hour of swimming a day, for the next 10 years left me in a shape that I was pretty proud of. And two hours of study a day left me comfortably cruising through tests and assignments. But now the situation had flipped. Now I could stand up for myself the bully was no longer around to be crushed. So ever so slowly I just got on with my life.

The Wandering

Then I graduated. The last time I had felt anger over my past was in yr9. Back in the rough years when my parents were going through divorce, I was helpless and the future was bleak. But I had made it out, escaped. I was sure that I was over it.

The Reunion

But by a chance glance across a street on the way back from the shopping mall, I saw him. He was no longer fit but out of shape. He was no longer immaculately dressed but in casual clothing. And he no longer had cronies around him. But it was him, 100%.

I followed him, the old venomous thoughts were rising.

I followed him, not even sure what I was going to do to him if I caught up. Just when I was about to overtake him I heard someone shouting “Dad! Dad!” and from behind me ran up a little girl followed by a smiling young woman whom I assumed was her mother. My bully’s face lit up as he dropped everything he was holding (shopping) and swept her up into his arms.

I wanted to stay angry. Really I did. But he just looked so happy and his family looked so happy. Three thoughts came to mind.

  • The first was; I went through the pain of not having a happy family. There is no way ever that I was doing anything to a happy family.
  • The second was; Children and wives have to believe certain things about their fathers and husbands respectively for them to be happy. There was no way I was going to ruin theirs.
  • The third was; People change. He wasn’t the same man and I certainly wasn’t going to stay the same venomous, rage-driven, unhealthy past self.

My thoughts were interrupted by my bully laughing. He glanced at me whilst I was staring and from his lack of reaction he certainly didn’t recognise me. I gave him a smile and walked away. The old demons were buried for good and I was going to get on with the life I was blessed to live.

Updated November 8
What is a great movie that started with the ending?

Extraction

Directed by Sam Hargrave, Extraction begins with a very interesting scene where Chris Hemsworth’s character Tyler Rake is engaged in a gun fight with elite forces on a bridge. This part shows exactly what the ending scene looks like and then switches back to the beginning. It gives the audience some excitement, leaving them questioning about whether he’s going to survive or not.

Such a great movie indeed.
